IRS990.MissionDescription: The Portland Museum of Art strives to enrich the lives of people through acquisition, preservation, and interpretation of the visual arts and the Museum's architecturally significant buildings.
IRS990.Description: Educational Programs: Create outstanding educational programs and collection-based activities to inspire and enrich the lives of diverse audiences and serve as a vital cultural center for the city and region (43,350 participants in 2009).

Activity2.Description: Exhibitions and Collections: Originate outstanding exhibitions from the Museum's permanent collection and through borrowed works of art. Present traveling exhibitions that support and extend the Museum's mission. Preserve, document, and interpret eighteen-thousand objects in the collection and five architectural landmarks (155,948 visitors in 2009).

Activity3.Description: Collection Items Purchased: 27 works of art were purchased for the Museum's collections in 2009, providing new opportunities for visitors and the community to experience original work.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The art collection and library of the Museum are reflected in the plant fund at a nominal value. The cost of a collection item is recorded as a decrease in net assets when purchased. The proceeds from the sale of a collection item are recorded as an increase in net assets when sold. The collection is managed according to a policy which adheres to the standards of the American Association of Museums. The policy delineates responsibilities in such matters as museum ethics, acquisitions, loans, care of collections, and deaccessioning. Objects held in the collection are carefully tracked and monitored. The Museum's deaccessioning policy allows for sale or trade of an object only when it is incompatible with the Museum's collecting mission and when clear and complete title to the work is confirmed. Proceeds from the sale of an object may only be applied toward collection acquisitions.

The Museum's collection contains more than 17,000 fine and decorative works of art dating from the 18th century to the present. The holdings include paintings, sculpture, prints, photography, glass and ceramics, artists' books, furniture, and other media. Works by artists such as George Bellows, Frederic Church, John Haberle, William Harnett, Childe Hassam, Marsden Hartley, Winslow Homer, Edward Hopper, Rockwell Kent, Fitz Henry Lane, Louise Nevelson, John Frederick Peto, Maurice Prendergast, John Singer Sargent, Andrew Wyeth, and Marguerite Zorach showcase the unique artistic heritage of the United States and of the state of Maine. The major European movements, from Impressionism through Surrealism, are represented by Marc Chagall, Gustave Courbet, Claude Monet, Edgar Degas, Rene Magritte, Edvard Munch, Pablo Picasso, and Pierre-Auguste Renoir, among others. The educational mission of the Portland Museum of Art is based upon the collection and the Museum adheres to the best practices of the American Association of Museums in developing and managing these works of art in the public trust.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Organization's intended use of endowment funds is for general operations, education, maintenance of collection and buildings, acquisition of art for the collection, wages, and other related expenses.

FundraiserActivityInformation.Activity: Assessment of the Development office and fundraising program

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The Museum paid $3,220 for a membership fee and dues to Portland's Cumberland Club, for Mark H.C. Bessire, Director of the Museum. The Cumberland Club is adjacent to the Portland Museum of Art, and membership allows the Director to host meetings for the purpose of conducting Museum business. For example, in 2009 the board of trustees held a strategic planning retreat at the Cumberland Club.

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.DescriptionOfTransaction: Compensation for services rendered as an employee of the Museum. She is the wife of chief curator, Thomas Denenberg.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The Organization sells contributions of securities through its investment broker. All gifts of securities are sold as soon as administratively possible.

The art collection and library of the Museum are reflected in the plant fund at a nominal value. The cost of a collection item is recorded as a decrease in net assets when purchased. The proceeds from the sale of a collection item are recorded as an increase in net assets when sold. The collection is managed according to a policy which adheres to the standards of the American Association of Museums. The policy delineates responsibilities in such matters as Museum ethics, acquisitions, loans, care of collections, and deaccessioning. Objects held in the collection are carefully tracked and monitored. The Museum's deaccessioning policy allows for sale or trade of an object only when it is incompatible with the Museum's collecting mission and when clear and complete title to the work is confirmed. Proceeds from the sale of an object may only be applied toward collection acquisitions. Additionally, for various auctioned items, the Organization does not record revenue when items are donated, rather when the items are sold at the auction event. Items sold at auction totaled $131,300.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is distributed to the full board of trustees with sufficient time for each trustee to review it. The 990 is then discussed at a full meeting of the board of trustees, before the board votes to accept the 990.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A top priority for the Organization's trustees is to formalize its governance procedures. To that end, on May 26, 2010, the Organization's bylaws were approved to form a governance committee. One of the first tasks of this committee is to establish procedures for monitoring and enforcing compliance with the Organization's policies, including the conflict of interest policy.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The director search committee gathered information on director salaries from comparable museums with the help of Malcolm MacKay, search consultant from Russell Reynolds Associates. There were two compensation surveys that the committee used, one based on geographical region, and one based on museum budgets. The Committee relied on the knowledge, expertise, and advice of the search consultants as well as other staff at Russell Reynolds Associates (including the head of the non-profit consulting group portion of the firm) for help in determining a salary. In addition, the leadership of the committee did have access to the director's salary at his previous job. The committee determined a proposed salary and then negotiated with the director based on that number. The Museum has also established a human resource committee and has engaged the services of a human resource consultant to conduct a salary survey, establish salary ranges, and develop guidelines for implementing compensation decisions.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are made available to the public upon request.
The audit process has not changed from the prior year.
